wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 4/24/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Managers Account for 70% of Variance in Employee Engagement

Gallup’s new report, The State of the American Manager: Analytics and Advice for Leaders, states that at least 70% of the variance in employee engagement scores across business units can be attributed to managers and their performance. Further research reveals that one in 10 people possess high talent to manage, but that companies make poor managerial hiring decisions 82% of the time. By using predictive analytics, employers could maximize their talent potential in future hiring to determine their best existing leaders.

Global consumers say brands must be environmentally responsible

Market research institute GfK interviewed more than 28K people in 2014 and according to the results, 76% of consumers say that brands must be environmentally responsible. They broke it down by country and 94% of consumers in India agreed, whereas in the UK 70% agreed, and in the US 66% agreed. We thought this coordinated nicely with Earth Week, and serves as a reminder of how consumers can drive sustainable business action.

12 Ways to Be An Engaged Employee

With increasing research coming out about employee engagement and ties to employee happiness/satisfaction/productiveness, it’s no wonder more and more companies are trying every assessment tool out there. However, Gallup’s Q12 engagement assessment can help employees reflect on their position and work. The author poses the questions and offers advice on how to improve your responses.

Employers assuming more responsibility for employee financial wellness

Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s new 2015 Workplace Benefit Report suggests that adoption of financial wellness programs is becoming most common in large firms, where 48% responded as having a plan for employees, which was an increase from 35% in 2013. As organizations find new, creative ways to engage their employees in positive impact programs such as sustainability and volunteering, financial wellness is increasingly being included in program planning.

Employee Engagement: What Do Employees Want?

In this Q&A with bestselling author and journalist, George Anders, technology is discussed as not only a way to increase efficiency in the workplace, but as a way to deliver tools that provide employees with the freedom to be innovative, imaginative, and connect with others. His advice on what NOT to do? Don’t give people bad tools. Make sure they feel supported (from the tech-side, too!), the content is relevant, and don’t micromanage. Companies can’t assume that free pizza and Ping-Pong will solve all of their engagement problems, so technology provides the answer.
